intro: Corydalis alaschanica, commonly known as the Alaska corydalis, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It belongs to the family Fumariaceae and is characterized by its delicate, spurred flowers that typically bloom in shades of pink or purple. The plant features slender, branched stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Corydalis alaschanica is an herbaceous perennial that thrives in cool, moist environments, often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. Its unique floral structure and adaptability to high-altitude conditions make it a notable species in its native range.
